p: Vibrio cholerae, the bacteria that causes cholera, is naturally present in the environment, in particular in coastal and estuarine ecosystems. Rita Colwell devoted her life to studying Vibrio bacteria and their ecosystem. V. cholera, like other species within the genus, attaches to copepods; the survival of these bacteria and their multiplication consequently rely on plankton population density and environmental variables such as sea surface temperatures and the input of fresh water. 188 Floods combined with abnormally warm sea surface temperatures favor cholera outbreaks. 189 An early warning system based on climatic variables was subsequently developed to assess the risk posed by cholera in Chesapeake Bay, United States. Critically, the quality of public health services, access to clean water and sanitation, and political stability are basic factors impacting cholera outbreaks; a prime example is the recent epidemic in Yemen. 190 The emergence of many other water‚Äêborne diseases is climate sensitive 6, 191 and strongly associated with increases in rainfall extremes and hurricanes. For example, a large cryptosporidium outbreak followed floods from the Mississippi in Milwaukee in 1993, and various toxins and norovirus spread in Katrina's wake in Louisiana in 2005. 192
